This creates an immediately resolved promise, which means that the test below will always pass. A better way to do this would be

let resolve;
const success = new Promise(r => resolve = r);
onSuccess(() => { resolve(true); });
expect(await success).toBe(true);

I recommend making this test fail (maybe by changing the code, or maybe by removing the contents of the onSuccess handler) so you can be sure the solution you have is a valid test, instead of one that passes unconditionally.
